history.content:
I can't speak for 16A, but for 70 and 61A the best way to prepare and handle content is practice - if you're not taking the HW option in CS70, do the HW anyways (and if you are, you're getting a fair amount of weekly practice as is). 

For 61A, the best way to alleviate the stress is to focus on grabbing as many extra credit points as you can - this really helps going into exams, knowing you have a cushion in terms of grading, and easing off the pressure often improves your performance. 

Given your practical coding experience, I think you'll find 61B easier than 70 (61B is a lot more practical), so don't worry if this semester doesn't exactly go to plan in terms of your goals for declaration - that being said, constant practice and asking questions in lecture whenever you're confused is a great way to improve your understanding of the material.

children.subject:
Do you mind sharing how do you study for 70 now? I'd love to know!

Also, I will talk to a TA or professor soon...

Sure.

I took the class last semester along with two other techs (cs61b and ee16b). MT1 I got about 1.3 standard deviation below the mean. Prior to MT1, I studied about 15 hours per week for the class, and this included going to discussion, doing homework, reading the notes..etc. But truthfully, I was being a little lazy about the process. Post MT1, I started pre reading. Meaning before lecture I would set aside an hour or so to go over the notes. Post lecture I went over the note again, but more carefully. When a homework was released I immediately began scanning it over. Not actually doing it, but just trying to understand what the questions were asking and what topics I needed to really understand. I didn't really do anything differently with discussions, but I know some people who found it helpful to attend different sections to find a TA that suited them. I increased my time spent to about 20-22 hours per week and started attending OH more frequently. I ended up getting 1.1 standard deviation above the mean on MT2 and got 0.7 standard deviation above the mean on the final. 

In the end, I had to drastically change my approach to the class. Can't say this is the same for everyone as I had a friend who spent about half the time I did and ended up with the same grade.

Wow, I'm happy to hear things worked out for you!

Like you I spend a lot of time on the class, but probably not in the most effective way, so I'm going to have to rethink how I study for the class.

CS70 is a tough class. So don't beat yourself up if you are struggling with it. I found that I needed to dramatically change my approach to studying for that class post MT1.

Try to take a step back and diagnose why you are struggling with the material specifically, and be honest with yourself in this regard. Talk to a TA or one of the professors if you can't quite pinpoint this. Once you know why, or have a good idea of how you can improve, gradually begin to address these areas. Yeah, it will probably require extra time per week, but thats to be expected.

history.content:
I'm a CS-intended transfer taking CS 61A, CS 70, and EE 16A right now (my remaining lower divs besides 16B). I'm also in CSM for 70 and a 1-unit low-workload DeCal.

I'm in an bad situation because I'm struggling to grasp 70 material and I'm confused by 16A circuits. Obviously I don't have unlimited time to spend studying and spending a lot of time in 1 or 2 classes makes me fall behind a bit in the other 1 or 2 classes. At the same time I need to take some time preparing for software engineering interviews at major companies and startups. I should also mention the stress/pressure associated with declaring CS (I know I'm not unique in this regard).

Perhaps it's because it's my first semester that I don't have the best studying strategies or time management and so I would very much appreciate advice on how to handle these classes and thereby understand course content efficiently as well as declare the CS major.

For some background, I have been coding for many years (publishing web and mobile apps, winning at numerous hackathons), so I consider myself decent on practical coding, but I'm currently not the best at theory parts of software (which is CS).
history.subject: First Semester Advice
